awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Using mining waste as a feedstock for the production of chemicals from CO2 with genetically engineered Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project is the development of technology for use of sulfide mining waste streams as a novel energy source for the production of chemicals from CO2. Sulfide mining wastes pose a serious, perpetual environmental risk, and are continuously generated as by-products of mining operations. The sulfide minerals in mining waste also are viable energy source for a diverse community of microbes that derive their energy from the oxidation of these minerals. This biological oxidation releases significant amounts of energy from the rock. The energy released from one ton of sulfide mining waste is approximately equivalent to one barrel of oil. Approximately 95% of copper ores are found in sulfide-rich ore deposits and at about 20 million metric tons annually, constitute ~15% of mining waste (representing millions of barrels of oil).  From genetically engineered microbes, it is proposed to use this energy to generate chemicals from CO2. As such, sulfide waste streams represent a new high energy feedstock for the sustainable production of chemicals from CO2. This technology will improve the sustainability of mining and provide a non-agricultural, non-photosynthetic and economically attractive route to carbon-neutral chemicals.
 
This STTR Phase I project proposes to demonstrate the development of genetically modified A. ferrooxidans for the utilization of mining process waste streams as a feedstock for biotechnology applications. Readily available sulfur-rich waste streams produced during the traditional smelting processing of copper contain about 40% per metric ton of the energy of glucose, and about 20 million metric tons are produced annually in the U.S. These energy intensive waste streams are currently landfilled, and their environmental oxidation can lead to acid mine drainage. To leverage this opportunity, the ability to rationally engineer this species to produce isobutyric acid from atmospheric CO2 has been developed. The specific aims of this proposal are: 1) develop model reactor systems to characterize performance and operations using actual mine tailing feedstocks; 2) improve biological productivity through further metabolic engineering of A. ferrooxidans; and 3) develop a sophisticated techno-economic analysis of the novel bioprocess. In addition, a commitment from a mining company for access to a tailing feedstock supply and a site to construct and operate a pilot-scale plant will be secured. Accomplishing these goals will prepare for a future follow-on Phase II proposal to scale-up our technology, further characterize performance on actual process streams, and demonstrate large-scale process feasibility.

por.por_cntn:
This STTR Phase I award sought to develop sulfur-bearing wastes from the extractive industries for use as a new energy-dense feedstock in the biological conversion of CO2 to useful chemicals and fuels. The oil, gas, and mining industries necessarily produce millions of tons of sulfur and sulfide mineral wastes each year. Sulfur and sulfide mineral wastes oxidize to sulfuric acid when exposed to the air resulting in acidic drainages that mobilize toxic metals and acidify fresh water supplies. In the mining industry, these waste products are stored in large man-made storage facilities that pose of significant, perennial environmental hazard. The oil and gas industries rely on the consistent removal and use of solid sulfur by other industries to maintain their operations. Otherwise, sulfur is stacked up in large solid blocks for later use. In both these industries, there is no plan to mitigate the environmental risk of long-term storage of these wastes and byproducts. Sulfur and sulfide minerals are also very energy dense having similar energy densities as coal and sugar. Thus, these materials offer the potential of a new, alternative energy source. Unique bacteria, such as Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans, can derive all their metabolic from sulfur and sulfide minerals and use this energy to convert carbon dioxide for all their biological needs in a process similar to plants. Our team has developed the tools to engineer A. ferrooxidans and is pursuing applications where this bacterium redirects the energy from sulfur and sulfides to the production of chemicals and fuels.

                In this project, we sought to develop model bioreactor systems that demonstrated the potential of these sulfur-based materials as a viable feedstock for the production of biofuels and chemicals. In conjunction with Columbia University and a partner in the mining industry we successfully tested the sulfide mineral pyrite and actual mining waste in small bioreactors. We showed that pyrite and mining waste do support robust growth of bacteria and that engineered cells are capable of producing useful chemicals when grown on these materials. Importantly, we identified that the main mode of growth on sulfide mining waste was as a biofilm and these biofilms are slow growing and rate limiting for the purposes of commercial biofuel and chemical production. This is an important early result in the development of such a commercial application as it provides a clear strategy for improving the process going forward. We also investigated the potential of using sulfur as a feedstock. Using the same bacteria, we were able to demonstrate very efficient cell growth and impressive chemical production using sulfur. Our work also helped identify key cost drivers and technical challenges in any future commercial applications and are the basis of ongoing investigation. These are the first reports of engineered bacteria feeding on sulfur and sulfide minerals producing biofuels and chemicals from CO2. Continued development of such technologies will reduce the environmental impact of these important industries, provide new alternative sources of energy, increase the revenue and profitability of existing industry, more efficiently utilize existing infrastructure, utilize CO2, and help develop and diversify the bio-economy.
